harmony.physicalContactObject: black stainless steel water bottle with silver screw cap

Swing downward in short arcs, letting the weight pull your wrist much like a real hammer head while your closed fingers feel the cylindrical circumference of the bottle as the handle.

harmony.explanation: Excellent temporal alignment: crisp impact, rising resistance then sudden give matches visual split perfectly.

expressivity.physicalContactObject: black stainless steel water bottle with silver screw cap
expressivity.physicalSubstrateObject: white paper towel roll (partially used)
expressivity.contactUtilizationMethod: Grip the bottle just above its lower third so that most of the mass (the full metal body and any remaining liquid) sits forward of your hand, creating a head-heavy feel. Swing downward in short arcs, letting the weight pull your wrist much like a real hammer head while your closed fingers feel the cylindrical circumference of the bottle as the handle.
expressivity.substrateUtilizationMethod: Stand the roll upright on the table with the hollow core centered under the impact point. On the first contact, the densely wound outer layers and cardboard core offer moderate resistance similar to a watermelon rind. A firm follow-through punch forces the core to buckle and the paper layers to collapse, producing a clear, sudden drop of the bottle head as the roll caves inward – mimicking the "breakthrough" when the rind finally gives way.
expressivity.expectedHapticFeedback: The user should then experience a distinct "breakthrough" moment as the hammer penetrates the rind - a sudden release of resistance like breaking through a moderately tough shell
expressivity.explanation: Clear initial impact, progressive build of resistance, and a sudden release closely match the sensation of wood cracking and splitting.

expressivity.physicalContactObject: black stainless steel water bottle with silver screw cap
expressivity.physicalSubstrateObject: red and white beverage carton with screw cap
expressivity.contactUtilizationMethod: Grip the bottle just above its lower third so that most of the mass (the full metal body and any remaining liquid) sits forward of your hand, creating a head-heavy feel. Swing downward in short arcs, letting the weight pull your wrist much like a real hammer head while your closed fingers feel the cylindrical circumference of the bottle as the handle.
expressivity.substrateUtilizationMethod: Place the unopened carton upright so the plastic spout faces away from the strike zone. The laminated cardboard walls first feel stiff and resist the descending bottle much like a firm melon. When the blow is hard enough, the side panel buckles and a rush of air or liquid inside shifts, letting the bottle head suddenly sink several millimeters. That abrupt wall collapse and internal slosh provides the "shell finally cracked" sensation.
expressivity.expectedHapticFeedback: The user should then experience a distinct "breakthrough" moment as the hammer penetrates the rind - a sudden release of resistance like breaking through a moderately tough shell
expressivity.explanation: Sharp impact and pop deliver a convincing crack and release, though the liquid damping differs slightly from solid wood’s rigidity.
